{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3400971,"name":"oriya","username":"Oriya","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/2bfe46/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T09:58:58.991Z","cooked":"

My team has problems with our battery, everytime we remove it out of charging (fully charged) it loses energy really quickly. It hurts the robotâ€™s abilities and we donâ€™t know the reason. We charge them all the time and still this happens, even without using them the batteries percentage drops increasingly. Does this happen to other teams? And how did you fix it?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T09:58:58.991Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":85.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":467872,"topic_slug":"battery","display_username":"oriya","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66844,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/battery/467872/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3400978,"name":"","username":"Kully","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kully/{size}/264955_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T11:17:17.804Z","cooked":"

It can happen for a few reasons like high Internal resistance due to usage and time. Another reason when running the robot is high usage from too high current limits and such.

A few questions that can help:
What is the internal resistance(can be measured with a battery beak)?

How old are the batteryâ€™s?

What are your current limits?

Do you have a subsystem that uses a lot of current( flywheel accelerating and decelerating rapidly and repeatedly)?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-06-22T11:17:17.804Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":320,"readers_count":319,"score":74.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467872,"topic_slug":"battery","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54481,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor of ftc 12016 ðŸ–¤ðŸ¤Ž"},"post_url":"/t/battery/467872/2","custom_user_title":"Mentor of ftc 12016 ðŸ–¤ðŸ¤Ž","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3401040,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-22T17:32:45.074Z","cooked":"

Batteries have two big wear/failure modes. #1, the capacity decreases every time you use it (more loss for a deep discharge). #2, every once in a while, one of the cells just dies.

A Battery Beak wonâ€™t identify/quantify either of these.

If you want a way to roughly and cheaplycheck battery capacity, hook a 12 Volt bulb and multimeter to the battery and time how long it takes to go from fully charged to 10.5 Volts. A headlight is a good choice if you have one.

The bulb will draw (power rating in Watts/Voltage) Amps, so you can get a decent Amp-hours number.

Most teams label their batteries by year, and use former years batteries as practice or testing batteries only. Some teams also record how many charge/discharge cycles the battery has over its life. These batteries do go bad after a couple seasons, and youâ€™d expect to see the symptoms youâ€™re experiencing.

If this happens with all of your batteries, Iâ€™d check the current data in the driver station log viewer. Look at total current draw and at voltage. If the current draw isnâ€™t very low, you can check the current for individual circuits.

Battery will degrade over time. If youâ€™re using a battery from 5 years ago, it will hold less capacity. It is strongly recommanded to mark your battery by year and get put battery that are less energetic aside for testing only as many of the above mentioned.

If you have the right equipment such as a battery analyzer sold by andymark, you could load test your battery and figure out weather it reached its age. Video from andymark demonstrated how that is done.

Also it could be that youâ€™re not charging your battery properly. This could caused by bad charger setting or broken charger. Try a different charger to see if youâ€™re having the same problem. A battery beak is very useful to figure out the charging status of a battery.

Last but not least, it is possible that your motor is stalling due to programming issue, motor failure or stuck mechanism.

Batteries last about 3-4 yearsâ€¦max. Depending on the drive you haveâ€¦tank or swerveâ€¦they will will decrease with use and frequency. Also, temperature plays a huge factor on how long a battery will last. Too hot or cold will decrease the lifespan of the battery.

As mentioned above, keeping batteries for no more than 2 years, moving the older ones to practice, testing, or demo should get the most out of them. Put the year and month on them for proper rotation.

No speed charging them either. Trickle charging in the off season is best. It will not heat up the batteries. Having 4-8 batteries on hand for competitions just in case (4 for tank, 8 for swerve max) for what ever type of bot you have should suffice. Tanks usually have CIMs or NEOsâ€¦swerve will eat up the batteries depending on the setup you have.
